instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00164: What is 820-00164? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Finally getting around to triaging some of the boards I have laying around that won't power up.

I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that shows the green to orange on magsafe charger. Not really sure where to start with no power issues. I have the boardview up.

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.41
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.57
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.32
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5v
<RESISTOR>R7080</RESISTOR> - 16.30 V

Any insight on what to check next would be great. FYI this board saw liquid damage according to the previous owner. Would love to get it working since it's a 2.2 i7 8gb ram. Overall board looks clean.


Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Well I got the board to power up. <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> was 0v which led me to <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>. For whatever reason two resistors near <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> were missing. All traces are good. Now the issue I'm having is no video. No chime.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Do you get VCORE?
Check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors.
Also check <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> for corrosion.
Do you get 3V at <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, pins 7 & 3?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Yes to vcore.
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 1.8V

Yes 3.4v on pin 7 & 3

No corrosion on <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6101</CHIP>

All spi resistors good

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Additionally I did try a known working display. There is no chime as well. Not sure what else to check.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SVS_L</SIGNAL> - 3.32V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.32
<SIGNAL>DM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.29V

Now when I trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> I get 3.41 on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
So fan spins only if you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal?
Are you using original Apple  60/85W charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Sorry I wrote that wrong. I edited the post. Fan spins anytime I plug MagSafe in. Still having issue of no video, no chime. Using a 45w original Apple charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
There are about 20 SPI Termination resistors; did you check them all?
Try new BIOS...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Yes I tested each resistor and checked traces. All is good. What's involved in replacing the bios? Doesn't this need to be programmed first?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Try new BIOS dump, of course; not another chip...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Sorry for my ignorance. I've never done that before. Any direction you can give me I'd appreciate. (I'll start googling) haha

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Do I need a chip programmer for this? Searching didn't come up with much.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message:
Usual external programmer requires to remove the chip.
Medusa programmer can do the job onboard, through J6100 connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power
threads.message: Problem resolved. Dumping the bios fixed the issue. Thanks again!
